name: Sokrates
description: For Eisenstein Socrates symbolized the best way of teaching - by asking questions instead of giving answers. Eisenstein loved teaching and implemented the “Socrates-Method“.

name: Mei Lanfang
description: Eisenstein was fascinated by Mei Lan Fan, considered the greatest actor of the Peking opera of his time. E felt strongly that it was important to use a tour of the Beijing Opera to film the unsurpassed art of transformation, the expressivity of facial movements, and graceful gestures of Mei Lanfang: the conventionalized language of Chinese theater could become a school of figurative thinking in general. E planned a film with him that remained unrealized.

name: Paul Robeson
description: On 23 December 1934, at the Belorusskii railway station, Eisenstein met Paul Robeson at the Belorussia railway station. Eisenstein had succeeded in having Robeson invited to the USSR, hoping that he would not only give concerts, but would also play General Dessalines in "The Black Consul." One trace of the unrealized project is a set of gramophone records given to Eisenstein by the singer.

name: Don Quixote
description: Eisenstein played Don Quixote in a short film he shot during the first congress of European film in La Sarraz in 1928. Together with members of the European Avantgarde who acted various parts the film he portrayed the struggle of independent cinema.

name: Mexican Carpets
description: Eisenstein worked on a film about Mexico depicting the local co-existence of several historical forms of society. Even though his Mexican film was stopped by Stalin, his time in Mexico represented the happiest time in Eisenstein’s life. He felt that in the Mexican landscape he recognized a portrait of his soul

name: Straw Horseman
description: E met the playwright Ernst Toller in Berlin. According to Eisenstein's memoirs and the story told by Pera Atasheva, at the end of the visit, Toller said that according to Eastern custom, the guest could choose something from the host's house as a keepsake. Feeling shy, Eisenstein began to look for something that Toller had two of. Finding two horsemen, he pointed to one of them. Toller turned pale but neatly wrapped the gift and handed it to him. Later Eisenstein found out that the horsemen had been a gift from the actress Elisabeth Bergner, with whom Toller was in love, and she only brought him souvenirs from her travels. After the Nazis came to power, Toller emigrated and all his possessions were lost. But the straw horseman was preserved in Eisenstein's house, thus proving another Eastern wisdom: "what you give away, you keep forever."

name: Vsevolod Meyerhold
description: Eisensteins close friend and teacher Vsevolod Meyerhold, killed in Stalin's dungeons. Eisenstein risked his life by saving Meyerhold's archive.

name: Sergey Prokofiev
description: According to Eisenstein, he and Prokofiev would always “bargain” for a long time before it was decided who should be first to make the next decisive audiovisual step. This would be a choice between the composer having to write the music having seen the relevant section of unedited film, or to compose it once Eisenstein had already edited it. With respect to the first choice, it would be up to the film director to develop the montage from Prokofiev’s existing score; with the second option, the principal artistic choices, in the form of his film montage, would already have been made by Eisenstein.
